reviewText:
Deeply, Deeply, Deeply flawed. It wants to be a stealth action game drenched in gritty realism, but the level of bad game design decisions and massive number of bugs keep me from recommending this game to anybody.

* Don't expect to be able to avoid or sneak past encounters. Several guards and soliders carry critical items you'll need to proceed. Which guards, you may ask? The game won't tell you until they're dead.

*AI alternates between being too dumb to breathe and psychic supersoldiers. Sometimes enemies will spot you even though you're clearly in complete darkness. Sometimes they won't. Sometimes enemy soldiers won't be able to shoot you on full auto from three feet away. Sometimes you'll blink and fall over dead. Sometimes you'll kill an enemy and it will be completely silent. Sometimes it will alert the enemies the next room over.

* The shooting mechanics are bad, supposedly to discourage mindless combat. But then the game forces mindless combat on you, most of the time without warning you.

* The environments look good, but they'll repeat themselves so many times it legitimately feels like you're just playing the same level again and again.

* Checkpoints happen once every 20-30 minutes. In gameplay sections with lots of enemies where most of your time is spent waiting doing nothing, this can get very frustrating very fast.

Whatever this game's strengths, they're far overshadowed by really poor design and technical mishaps that really takes me out of the experience. Can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Velvet Assassin is a much better game in theory than in practice. It has a great premise: a likable female spy who brutally assassinates Nazis to secretly turn the tide of WWII. To be clear, Velvet is a stealth game clearly designed for sneaking, and yet the stealth gameplay can be exceptionally frustrating.

The sneaking system is woefully underdeveloped. There are no visibility indicators or radars or cones of vision. Trial and error is all you have. Then there’s the painfully slow sneaking speed. If you remain undetected, you get rewarded with truly great kill animations. If an enemy spots you, you have to run away or rely on wonky combat and AI exploits.

The game is very linear, with a sort of paint by numbers approach to stealth, resulting in you either going about things the developers’ way or repeatedly dying. The checkpoint system can also be irksome, with some checkpoints quite far apart, making you fearful to fail simply because you don’t want to replay things again.

On the bright side, the story and briefing cutscenes are done very well, building up believability and intrigue. Very strong voice acting by all characters is also a great boon, with humorous enemy dialogue akin to No One Lives Forever being a highlight. Certain mechanics like shadows, whistling, and stat upgrades do help keep things interesting. Graphically the game is bleak, brown, and barren but occasionally looks quite nice.

Overall, Velvet Assassin only takes about 6 hours to finish on Normal, which is good because by the end I was very ready for it to be over. Despite the frustration there’s something charming about its very old school approach, almost daring you to try to survive. The game clearly isn’t great, but it does have some good elements. Most will wish to skip the game, but for those hardcore gamers who find the concept intriguing, Velvet Assassin is worth playing if you pick it up for real cheap.

According to one of my friends, the game can be played on newer graphics cards but speaking from personal experience on a GTX 560 Ti, I can't play this.

reviewText:
Velvet Assassin is an excellent game, let me tell you why.

PROS:
You're an agent behind enemy lines and you have to take out important people or sabotage bases. The gameplay is great, the stealth system fairly simple; hide in shadows, don't walk in front of people, but it can get pretty intense, especially the later levels where there are less shadows to hide in and you need to perform more daring assassinations on patroling enemies.

The weapons you get are true to the era (no crossbows or whatever), fitting for an assassin: a knife and a pistol. You can't carry around clunky weapons on your back like you're some sort of Wolfenstien. However there are portions of the game where, after blowing something up, you need a less tacticle approach to escape and the shotgun is your friend. It makes sense, it doesn't seem realistic that you can be a ghost 100% of the time. Besides, if you don't go out with a bang, how are the Nazi's gonna know you were there? :)

Content, I've played the game for about 8 hours and I'm not even halfway done. There's also rewards you get for exploring, albiet within the confines of the level. Not every game has to be open world/sandbox. Also, it seems there's a new way to kill enemies almost every level. The levels are also pretty unique from each other, and a lot of effort was put into level design. It doesn't get dull.

Great voice acting. Excellent grahpics. Nice execution animations.


CONS:

You can't pick up enemy weapons, which may be helpful if you get discovered. But I guess an assassin doesn't want to be loud even if she's getting shot at.

The story is a little disjointed. There isn't too much of a connection between missions, but it doesn't hurt to use your imagination a little bit and pretend that the British sent you on a new mission somewhere else, leaving the old mission behind you, cause after all it's finished.

Very rarely the character movements and controls seem unnatural, like when you're trying to sneak around a corner and you have your face pressed right up to it. It's not enough to detract from the fun though. And I feel it's due to the Nvidia physix engine (AMD users can still play the game though!).

Checkpoints happen about four or five times during a mission. If you're trying to play a perfect game, be prepared to reload. But, it's challenging! Not a kill an enemy

reviewText:
Velvet Assassin is a fantastic game, with the elements and features that make third person spy/stealth games great. I found this game genuinely chilling and has numerous dark themes throughout. The devs really nailed it when it comes to the enemies in this game - I quickly learned how hostile and realistically powerful they are. This combined with their ferocious barks in German made me genuinely dread running into one around a corner, or being exposed in broad daylight in near proximity. Playing through each of the somewhat diverse levels (all of which are very dark and gritty - don't expect sunshine, mountains and waterfalls), requires logical thinking. I say this in terms of traversing between light and shadow, and studying each guards movement patterns before moving forth, being prime examples. I like this element as I felt even more engaged in the role of Violette, and in the precarious situations with her.

Despite the challenging and what I found to be personally enjoyable gameplay, I found the storyline was Velvet Assassin's greatest downfall. Throughout the game I found myself puzzled as to where Violette's fight for the Resistance would lead, and did not understand the relation between missions during early parts of the game. It was during the latter portion that I developed a better understanding for her purpose and started seeing a connection between the missions. This is the part of the review which will explain how my player-engagement and excitement quickly turned sour. It was only just as I was becoming heavily invested in the story, that I was completely disappointed.

Velvet Assassin, has one of the most disappointing endings to a video game I have EVER seen.

I of course will not reveal why, as I am not going to spoil the ending. But it was incredibly disappointing.

I would still recommend this game for people to play, for all the other gameplay positives I have highlighted in this review, however I am still shocked by this game's conclusion.

See for youself.

I found this game to be one of those games that teaches you to tolerate a new level of frustration.  Velvet Assassin is a stealth game, plain and simple.  You basically solve puzzle after puzzle on a completely linear path with a half-baked story, set sometime during WWII. You might spend 20 - 30 minutes within a given area scouting, and trying to figure out the best course of action, only to be killed by a rogue soldier, and then you get to start from the beginning of the checkpoint, repeating all of the progress you've just made. I like games that steadily progress, but in this game, I found myself redoing scenes of play, over and over, until I completed each part exactly the way the designers of the game wanted me to.

I would label this a very mediocre game, with a large portion of frustrating mechanics.  I would not wish this game on my worst enemy.  Do not even start playing this game if you value keeping your brain as a single solid mass, and not a skull full of  scrambled mush.

Velvet Assassin is a solid game that has a few quirks to it, but overall doesn't take away from your experience.

As you've seen in the forums for this game, you need to download a specific PhysX driver. You can install it over your existing drivers. I had no problems running this on Windows 8.1.

The main sneaking mechanic is very basic. When your icon glows purple you can't be seen. When it doesn't, you're exposed. I wish there was some sort of fading system to this so I could tell when i'm pushing my limits of being in the shadows. It's an on/off switch.

FYI, you cannot replay individual missions. Even after you beat the game. So if you are a collector and missed some items during a level, you better replay it from one of the checkpoints before progressing further.

I had about 3 total crashes that just abruptly sent me back to the desktop. Enough to note but not to complain about.

Pros
+Graphics style is nice.
+Autosave system is fairly frequent.
+Assassination animations are always satisfying.
+Price. I got the game for 49 cents. Unbelievable deal!
+Multiple ways of solving each mission.
+No huge difficulty spike. It trends nicely.
+Interesting and diverse enviornments
+Smooth constant 60fps

Cons
-Repetitive enemy noises and sayings
-Morphine is a get out of jail free card
-Forced to use guns toward the end of the game.
-Sneaking system very basic
-I never got into the plot.
-You need to exploit the stealth mechanics and enemy AI a lot.
-Pet peeve of spawned enemies occurs several times. Relies on some trial and error.
-Addition of manual save for PC port would have been nice

Bottom Line
Stealth games are surprisingly relaxing for me to play. Sneak around, watch guard patterns and execute your moves. Velvet Assassin was what I expected. The core mechanics for a stealth game are here, but feel like a lot could have been improved.

Final Score
6.5/10 - Good game. Can't go wrong for just a buck or two.

reviewText:
This is a pretty neat game despite how rough the experience can get at times. You play as Violet, a secret agent who really likes stabbing nazis. The story isn't one of the game's strong suits and it doesn't need to be, because the stealth gameplay is quite good and is complemented by pretty well designed levels.

The challenge is really good as the AI can be quite nasty at times and any mistake will punish you. There's a variety of ways you can take out nazi scum and they're all equally satisfying, be it electricuting them, stabbing them in the balls, or pulling one's grenade pin and turning him into a walking time bomb unbeknownst to him and his buddies he's chatting with. There's even a little bit of Hitman-style stealth where you can sometimes put on an SS uniform as a disguise (which Violet looks quite cute in). For a game released in 2009 it looks quite nice, and comparable to titles released even six years later.

The game isn't without its flaws though, and they're pretty ugly ones, the worst being the save system being checkpoint-based. To me, checkpoints have no place in stealth games, and this one stinks on ice. Stealth is a genre where you're constantly in delicate situations, and one little mistake will just mess everything up. Having checkpoints be minutes apart is just abusive, and it's not helped by the ludicrous AI. I like a good challenge in my stealth, but it was often that the AI felt just downright ♥♥♥♥ing clairvoyant. If you spook a nazi, no matter how or where he'll just converge on your position. You can make a noise and sneak to the other side of the damn area and he'll keep following you, almost as if he just knows you're there. Another thing I think has no place in stealth games is forced action/shooting segments, and there's more than a handful present. The game really falls apart in the last stage because of this, as it's almost nothing but forced gunfights. There's also the occasional bug here and there but what modern game doesn't have those.

This game has been undeservedly neglected since its release six years ago. Despite its nasty flaws, there's a lot to like here, and it feels good to play a game that'll push my ♥♥♥♥ in for any mistake I make, especially in an age where stealth has fallen from grace and has been relegated to garbage pseudo-stealth you see in big-name games nowadays. Not to mention it's so damn cheap you'd be wrong not to give it a shot.

Hell, if it's too hard for you, you can even mess with config files and make it easy for your casual baby butt to handle.

reviewText:
Overall 7/10

Velvet Assassin is a pretty basic “old-school” stealth game, however, the mechanics are solid and the unique setting and well thought out presentation turn it into an overall good game for people that like the genre. If you didn’t like the likes of Thief or the older Splinter Cell titles or need massive freedom in approaching your strategy like in Dishonored, Velvet Assassin will certainly not change your mind.

The title is very linear and the majority of time you spend crouching in shadowy corners, figuring out enemy patrol patterns and move slowly in for the kill, hoping you didn’t miss any observant Nazi in viewing or hearing distance. The enemy AI is not that good, they follow their patterns and investigate suspicious activities. Your hero Violette is not Solid Snake and there not many gadgets or weapons to be used, mainly it’s you, your knife and the shadows. The difficulty level is high and most of the time there is only one right way to get through a scenario. This means a lot of Trial & Error (and repetition due to a checkpoint system), but it makes success rewarding and the controls are precise enough to almost never make it frustrating. The almost comes from some forced action sequences that can get overwhelming too easily especially toward the end of the game.

Velvet Assassin takes itself serious, there is no humor to be found, the world is dark and depressing, but at the same time beautifully presented. This is very fitting for the World War 2 setting that is relatively fresh for this kind of game. The narrative structure interesting, full of dark themes and delivered by solid voice actors, overall I would call the game emotionally engaging and that is one of the things that definitely make it worth playing, even though the gameplay doesn’t offer that much variety. The campaign is relatively short and things wrap up before they can get boring.

I recommend Velvet Assassin to all stealth fans or gamers that are interested in a darker more personal World War 2 setting, definitely worth playing and the short campaign won’t take that much time to finish.

Pros:
- emotionally engaging
- solid stealth mechanics
- good story in a beautiful setting

Cons:
- linear (not much freedom) and short
- frustrating forced shoot-outs

reviewText:
Have you ever thought of yourself as a cold blooded killer focused on your mission to eradicate the Nazi scourge infecting 1940’s France? Then this is the game for you

This game is a great third person action/stealth game with a fairly good combat system. The game is full of tense moments and tight confined spaces. You can approach almost every situation by either gunning down everything that breathes (you will die quickly) or you can sneak around in the shadows and strike decisively and killing indiscriminately before fading away leaving the remaining Nazi’s to wonder who you will butcher next. Also with the addition of Morphine mode you become indestructible and storm through everyone that stands in your way.

The story, based rather loosely on real life events, is sparse but enjoyable, not everything has to be massively in depth but here is enough going on to keep you interested and playing. It’s pretty standard for a world war two spy setting, your job is to defeat bag guys and gain intel. It does take place in retrospective, you see what’s going to happen but it’s the getting there that’s interesting. The characters themselves though are rather two dimensional to be honest, it’s hard to pin down why but I didn’t feel particularly connected to Violette, even when the story develops.

Pick this game up and enjoy the ride, especially if it’s on sale. The game has not aged amazingly and there were several glitches, none of which game breaking. However I had a good time with it right up to the end before the final mission changed everything. So as with a lot of games from this era I would recommend playing it but don’t feel the need to finish it.

Have fun ^_^

There's little instruction besides wait for the two guards to separate (which is semi-obvious), and you're pretty much on your own to figure out how to pass the second guard after taking out the first, something I wasn't able to do.  Had this happened later in the game, I'd accept it as a tricky part of a stage, but having this happen right in the beginning of the game is extremely frustrating.  Maybe I'll come back to this some day, but for now I've uninstalled it.  It's hard to get into a game when I can't even pass the beginning section without massive difficulty.  More dedicated players or people who like stealth games might enjoy this.  But given what I see as excessive difficulty right in the beginning of the game, I can't really recommend this.\n\nUpdate:  Thanks to a comment on this review, I finally passed the intro mission and got to the next one.  However, I still don't really like that the intro wasn't a self-walkthrough, and I'm still finding the game overall to be slow-moving and rather difficult, even very early on.  That's probably the point here, but I'm not really enjoying it.  Every time I die at a harder part, I have to redo the easier parts before it, and this happens over and over again, making things feel repetitive.  Also, in some sniper games I played recently, I felt like I had a fighting chance if I got spotted, but here I feel like I'm just dead meat.  Maybe this isn't my type of game.  Perhaps in small doses, it will be OK, but I think I'll just end up frustrated if I try to play this for a long time at once.  As I said originally, if you like this type of game in general, you'll probably like this specific game, but I don't think it's for me, and for more casual gamers like me, I wouldn't recommend it because of the rather high difficulty level it seems to have.

reviewText:
Not exactly my usual preference of game but being of the WW2 variety I decided to take a chance as the last time I did so (Return to Castle Wolfenstein) my choice was proven a correct one.

Set in WW2 you assume the role of Violette Summer, which was inspired by a real life heroine by the name of Violette Szabo, which is an pretty incredible life story itself for anyone with a passion for history.  The mood of this game is what one would truly expect of war-torn Europe; bleak, fearful, violent and sad.  The opening movie pretty much sums the game up in my opinion, not to spoil it for anyone but it reminds me of that eerie opening to one of my favourite TV series; The World at War were humanity is destroying itself in an unforgiving darkened world.

Now your role as Violette is to infiltrate and end the lives of the darkest and most corrupt seeds in the Third Reich (well you blow stuff up too) in quick and quiet fashion then escape - no charging about like Master Chief, you're an assassin not god with a gun and a green suit because believe me this game can be unforgiving when caught.  Now I very much recommend a Xbox controller or something similar when play this game as the controls are very clunky even on controller, especially when shooting.  The visuals and sound are very satisfying and in-sync with the mood; sombre and eerie would be my quick description.  There is one mechanic that does stand out however and that is the morphine power, to put it simply when injected you enter a slow down mode where you can damn near do anything which does kill the immersion somewhat.  The A.I aren't too bright in the game either, then not many games pull that off but they are not without character.  They have seen war and it has touched them deeply and some of the conversations you hear are truly horrific.

Now this game is certainly not for everyone, but to anyone like me who plays stealthy characters in any game with the option to do so will feel right at home with this game.  You choose the right weapons for your mission, disguise yourself when necessary and gather intelligence when and if you can.

I would give this game a 4/5 for it truly is an enjoyable game with a few flaws.

reviewText:
Vicariously view violent Violette vehemently victimize valueless Nazis. I’m not sure why I went with the unneeded alliteration but I’m not sure why the developers went with velvet. Maybe they were trying to turn Violet into velvet for some reason but…whatever…

Velvet Assassin takes places in the early/mid 1940s. You’re a British assassin named Violette Summer who’s based off, in first name, hairstyle, and background only, of real world British assassin Violette Szabo[en.wikipedia.org]. Violette single handedly either takes out several high ranking Nazi leaders (who didn’t exist) or helped lead to the destruction of several Nazi outposts including the real-life mission Operation Gomorrah[en.wikipedia.org]. She does this with her well placed knife and a Nazi jugular vein. She also uses a silenced pistol but …ugh. More on this unfortunate mechanic later.

Stealth is both very good and very bad at the same time. Apparently, Nazi’s were very blind individuals. A light shade in otherwise broad daylight can keep them from noticing you. It seems odd that any darkness can be that good in a, mostly, realistic stealth game. The game does have a higher difficulty so if you want to skip the, “Does Violette have special shadow moving powers?” go ahead play that. I hear it’s painfully real. The game also has ‘Morphine Mode’, which allows you to travel unnoticed or get a face to face kill cam. It might seem like a supernatural power but you learn the first 10 missions are all flashbacks so morphine mode is a foggy memory of how Violette got that kill. The final two are “current time” missions.

As you go through missions you find collectables and hidden achievements (found through exploration) which, when you reach 1000 exp, allows you to upgrade a stat, either morphine mode; which increases syringe count and length, stealth; which allows you move faster, or strength; which makes you tankier. The collectables are various war medals and paraphernalia, some of which have interesting back stores but I feel like there could have been expanded to allow for more backstory. You might start feeling sympathy for Nazis through. There’s a few instances where the horrors of war appear all too human and you feel a little guilty as poor Gretchen won’t be seeing her husband because of you. They may be literal Nazi’s but they still dream and love like the good ol’ boys in [insert country flag colors here]. That’s one of the things the game does really well. The carnage of WWII is evident in every aspect of the game. Dead bodies litter the streets of Warsaw, Poland. Several children are apart of the body count as they hang in various trees in France. Some enemies are even given a soul when they wish none of this has happened and just want to go back home; not everyone follows the leader in war. There’s even one letter where the writer says he’s ready to die due to the nightmare reality.

VA has 12 missions which average out an hour of play time (not sure if time resets on death). Checkpoints are all over the place but getting to them can be very painful. The slowness of the game is apparent when you have to kill a large amount of enemies in a less than straight forward way where you get caught, die and have to try again. Missions like level 6 might be a game killer if you’re not dedicated. The first 10 levels are wonderful, albeit a crawl at times. “Realistic” stealth mechanics where hiding in the shadows, behind a crate, or disguised as the only female SS officer in the game are the way to victory as there’s not enough ammo to go Rambo. That all changes in the last two levels and therein is where the game devolves into pain.

You see, Velvet Assassin stops being about stealth and turns into a third person shooter. This would be fine but the shooting aspects are very poor. The crosshair is there but bullets don’t always go where you’d think, enemies can be randomly resistant to damage, and general aim abilities are just awful. You know how many games have ice levels and you don’t stop when you want to stop? That’s what aiming in this game feels like. If you move a little, it doesn’t move but if you move a lot you just turned 360 degrees while barely trying. This can be mitigated by using a mouse but even then it needs a lot of work. To exacerbate the terrible aiming, the stealth mechanic goes away. Enemies are suddenly more likely to see you, even in deep shadows and getting enemies alone where you can get a knife skill is nearly impossible and it comes from nowhere. You can get through all but one or two levels in the first 10 without shooting anyone but suddenly it’s the only way to progress.

Along with the sudden genre shift, the developers tried to add some sex to the game. Violette stops wearing jackets and black ‘armor’ and now dons only a white negligée (and the velvet in Velvet Assassin) due to story reasons. She’s also very shiny for, uh, ‘plot’. It turns a hardnosed female assassin into a male fetish. There’s no option to get dressed and even in the credit epilogue she’s in her underwear. It’s like the last two levels were done by a different team. The game could have been great but due to the ending levels, it turns itself into mediocre at best.

As for non-gameplay aspects: Voice acting it nice. Our Heroine sounds smooth and pleasant and at no point do you ever wish for her to shut-up. Maybe it’s the English accent (from a New York born, German for five years raised woman) or the lower tones but I’d like to hear Melinda Y. Cohen[en.wikipedia.org] more often.
The German enemies spoke German (with subtitles if you don’t speak the language) so there’s some immersion for ya.
Music is…eh. You hear the sound of gunfire too often and in places where you shouldn’t be hearing gunfire. It can also throw you off and make you think someone saw you. Otherwise, it’s all atmospheric. It ramps up when you’ve been spotted and it always makes me feel like I screwed-up when I hear it. Not sure if that was the purpose but that’s the outcome so, to be honest, I’m digging it. There are no official sources so here’s some Youtube videos. There’s actually more tracks than I thought and there’s less than one page in the link.

The art helps contribute perfectly to the doom and gloom of war. There are no vibrant colors and blue skies are replaced by a dark, dirty, orange. There aren’t even any stars in the sky. Everything else is stone, iron, and ground. No hope, no freedom, no future. Welcome to war. That being said, the Paris skyline from the river Seine (or what I think is the river) circa 1943 looks beautiful even in high overcast and fog.

The game has its sufferable flaws but for .49 USD cents which is what I paid for it during a summer sale (so the price of 8-16 cards), it’s well worth it. It’s a slow plough through the first 10 levels (which is what to expect from a stealth game) and the third person shooting genre change makes the game way less fun so at full price, don’t buy it; it’s not worth it. I really wish I could recommend at full price but my frustrations at needing to relearn the game 5/6ths of the way in makes It hard. File it under cult classic.

Troubleshooting:
For whatever reason, modern technology hates Velvet Assassin so, in order to play the game, you may need to download the Nvidia legacy driver located here[www.nvidia.com]. It’s free, fast, and easy.

reviewText:
Summary: Velvet Assassin has the atmosphere of Return to Castle Wolfenstein with the gameplay of a stealth game like Thief or Dishonored.  If you can forgive some functional issues (enemy-proof doors, sparse checkpoints, poorly explained interface), you’re in for a well-written adventure on the macro scale and thoughtfully crafted, varied stealth gameplay on the micro scale.

Pros and cons:

+ You have a variety of tools at your disposal.  You can sneak up and backstab a guard, or pull the pin on his grenade if he has one.  You can use one of your very scarce bullets, or use an environmental hazard like electrified water or poison gas barrels.  You can take a shot of morphine and charge an enemy before he can react.  You can stay in the shadows, break a fuse box to darken new areas, or hide in tall plants when outside.  You can also peek through keyholes before you enter a room, and whistle to draw the enemy away from his normal patrol route.
+ The game looks good, and the art supports the gameplay.  Strong shadows make it clear whether you’re hidden in the dark or not.  The enemies don’t look like clones of each other, which helps you keep count of everyone when sizing up a room.
+ The story ties things together well.  A large part of the game is presented as the protagonist recounting her adventures.  So she says things like “I had to find a key” which sounds better than her talking to herself in the present.  A major plot point is foreshadowed bit by by bit through flash-forwards.  The enemy guards frequently have long conversations with each other which, along with the collectible treasures, enrich the experience and sound very authentic.

- About half of the doors seem to load a different section of the map.  Enemies can’t follow you through these doors.  So no matter how hot things get, if you can reach a ‘load’ door you’re totally safe.
- The game only saves at checkpoints, which are often annoyingly far apart.  Most enemy encounters have one of two outcomes: you execute your plan perfectly, or you die and start over.  There’s not much middle ground, so even with upgraded health, most of the medkits go unused.
- While the game isn’t totally linear, player movement is tightly controlled.  You can only crawl, jump, or climb at specific places where the game allows it.  Invisible walls insure you can never step off a ledge, or even wade through a foot-deep pond.  So basically, don’t expect ‘outside the box’ thinking to get you anywhere.
- Some of the interface and instructions are confusing.  For example, you don’t use ‘aiming mode’ to backstab somebody.  Even though you raise your knife and it looks like exactly what you’re supposed to do, you’ll clumsily poke the guard, and almost certainly get shot before he dies.  You *can* get more than one morphine needle, but you need to upgrade your morphine multiple times.  There are things like this that weren’t communicated well, which you’ll have to figure out through trial and error.

A somewhat mediocre, but very good third-person shooter released 5 years ago (2009). You are Violette, a British female spy who attempts to weaken Nazi Germany in World War II.

The game employs a stealth-based gameplay-style characterised by the following things:

--shadows are your best friend and you can hide without soldiers being able to see you
--this is a must - once you are seen it is difficult to survive the firefight
--you have morphine syringes at your disposal: once you use these the game becomes slow-mo and you can easily eliminate the guards who have noticed you; you need to look for these syringes as you can quickly run out of ammo"
--wearing a disguise: Violette can pick up an SS uniform which means you can move freely amongst the German soldiers; you cannot get too close to them and you need to be careful as to what action you perform

Violette receives experience points which allow you to upgrade her skills. This is just a minor RPG element and to be honest nothing unusual or exciting. Also
date: the more collectibles you find the more XP you can collect - it's worth looking around wherever you go on each level.\n\nThe game is OK for its price
recommended: especially if discounted (the last time it cost 0.99 EUR). reviewText:
Velvet Assassin is a WWII-based 3rd person game and is basically a simplified version of known stealth games like Splinter Cell.

Due the game taking place in the 1940s, there aren't any nifty gadgets to assist you, so the shadows are your most valuable tool. Ammo for the few weapons you find in the levels is rare, but since the shooting mechanics are horrible that doesn't even matter anyway.

Moving through the levels without being spotted requires a certain amount of tactics and timing, but luckily, by whistling, you can lure enemies into dark places to take them out silently with a variety of brutal takedown animations.

The biggest drawback of the game is the save system. With no manual saves, you have to rely on the rarely placed checkpoints, which - due the nature of the game - can be a very tedious and frustrating task, especially when going for an unarmed full-stealth playthrough.

VA is a game you *can* get, but you certainly won't miss out on anything if you don't.

reviewText:
In the veins of Hitman (and I mean close enough that 47 would feel uncomfortable) lies this hidden little game. To my knowledge the company that made this shortly closed after the game's release, which is a shame because they could've patched this to be a great game or have worked on a sequel which wouldn't contain the same problems this faces.

Let's start with the obvious, shall we? The stealth mechanics in this game are a massive pain in the backside offering large amounts of frustration and jankyness. Guards that have the inexplicable ability to see around corners, their seemingly amazing eyesight from several hundred metres armed with sub-machine guns that act more like sniper rifles and the fact your silenced pistol will be completely useless the majority of the time add to a VERY perplexingly bad disguise system (Worse than the Hitman: Absolution one) makes this incredibly annoying.

The level design is often vague and poorly chosen too. Very few times will you fairly have a chance to avoid the Nazis patrolling around and instead have to pick several of them off one by one until the majority have been thrown off a cliff with a knife lodged somewhere in their neck. This leads to ENDLESS amounts of restarts because somehow you were spotted around a corner lodged in a bush and naturally, you can't survive more than a handfull of bullets. Even when things do go your way, checkpoints are few and far between and often after SEVERAL incredibly difficult scenarios in which you'll be beggining for a break.

The amount of content itself is nice though, you have a decent amount of levels often taking more than 20 minutes to complete in a good run, accompanied by collectibles (if that's your thing). The morphine feature is incredibly useful too. It stops time (removing your clothes too?) and allows you to have a clear escape from the people about to turn you into a bullet-ridden english woman.

All in all, I honestly wouldn't recommend this to anyone who's not INTENSELY desperate for a stealth game when the Hitman Franchise, Splinter Cell (minus Conviction and Double Agent) and Alien Isolation exist. Go elsewhere for your sneaky stabby fix.

reviewText:
This game is about a British Agent who fell into a coma state after being shot while completing a mission.  During her time at the hospital, she has flashbacks of all her previous missions where she sabotages German plans in WWII (you play those missions).  After all the flashbacks, she wakes up and has to escape because Germans are looking for her and get back home.

I think I got this from a bundle by IndieGala.

As a serial pervert I loved this game because:
1. Main protagonist is hot.
2. There are missions where you strut around in a military uniform and that fulfills my fetish desires
3.  She also struts around in a nightgown/underwear in a few levels or when she takes morphine
4.  She wears spandex in a few levels too.  If you look carefully, you can see traces of her underwear too.
5. When she wears her nightgown, the bottom portion of it is see through, and you can see her crotch slightly.

What this game needs to improve on:
1. Adult scenes
2. Undercover missions where the main has to pretend to be a sex slave.

Jokes aside (or really?), check the forums and download the patch if the game won't load.  This game plays like metal gear solid or splinter cell but don't expect that kind of game.  I played the game thinking it was more of an indie game than big company stuff and I thought it was really nice.  The AI is unpredictable in stupid ways and it can turn people off.  Sometimes they are blind as a bat - you kill his teammate next to him but in the shade and he can't see it but sometimes you stand in the shade and they detect you.  Also, the last 2-3 missions are significantly harder.  The game auto saves only and sometimes between checkpoints there are a lot of things that you have to repeat doing if you die.  One thing about this game is the linear pathing (can't skip mobs) and it is meant to be played stealth most of the time rather than brute force because of the ammo/disadvantage situations you are in.  I thoroghly enjoyed the game though as you can see the hours played (no I did not leave the game open and afk'd).

reviewText:
A great game so far. Although there are an awful lot of reasons NOT to buy this game, but there is also reasons why you SHOULD buy it.

I bought it in this summer sale for: £0.39 which isn't a bad price at all, I downloaded it and realised i needed more drivers for graphics and also my hardware, which wasn't a problem on my end but the games instead. After about 10 minutes of playing I was drawn in by the graphics and also the physics of the game. I have to say, not bad for a £3.99 game.

As I carried on playing I found a few... Cons, so to say, some of the AI / NPC's were lacking well... Realism.
I could kill someone in plain sight and if someone came over, they would not notice the body. But most of this was avoided as I killed most of my opponents with melee steath then pulled them away for good measures.

As expected in a 3rd person video game which doesn't involve much tatical thought, was the lacking gun play style, I had countless Issues of which I would randomly change weapon or even not end up shooting at all, which was rather annoying. But I soon conqured this in no time after I had about 3 - 4 restarts.

But overall I have enjoyed the first part of the game and ver interested in the story and how it will progress. On a rating of /10 I would give it: a solid 8 / 10.

reviewText:
Worth $5?  Sure.  On sale?  Definitely!  For the 75 cents I paid for it, it was well worth it.  It's an old school stealth game that runs on rails.  But that doesn't automatically make it bad.  The plot was great and the story development felt involved, even if it was scripted.  The mechanics were a little clunky, but were pretty straight forward and they worked well enough.

It's got some negatives. Checkpoint saves instead of real ones, artificial limits on weapons & ammo to force you to play it stealthily, and an ending that just didn't work for me (a shift from stealth to forced combat at the end, and an unsatisfactory ending to the game), and other pretty minor gripes.  But all in all, a fine purchase for the price, several entertaining hours of play, and better value than anything else I've bought for under a buck in a long time!  Just don't set your AAA game expectations when you get it - compare it to indy titles or other old games that you paid a comparable price for and you'll be very happy with it.

A worthwhile B- or C+ in my book.

reviewText:
Velvet Assassin interested me when I first saw its gameplay. Games where stealth is the primary focus are not made that often. However, after seeing the relatively average review scores on Metacritic and Steam, I decided to wait for the price to drop. After seeing it for about $1 on Steam I decided to buy it. Let’s just say it turned out to be worth much more than $1. While the game obviously doesn’t have the massive budget and polish of AAA stealth games like Metal Gear Solid, it’s still a great game. You traverse through a great variety of levels, often equipped with nothing but a knife and pistol with few bullets. You generally need to stay hidden since all the Nazis have automatic weapons and you are rather defenseless making this a true stealth game. Running and gunning is rarely an option when up against multiple opponents. The storyline is virtually non-existent and is there just for the sake of having one. Graphics and audio are above average. The game is about 10 hours long.

Bottom Line: If you’re looking for another stealth game to play, then Velvet Assassin is for you.

reviewText:
In this game you play as a British agent dirupting operations of German stabilization forces across multiple countries during events of the WWII. Narration and story is the strongest side of this game and truly shows that war never changes. As a titular assassin your task is to eliminate targets by any means necessary and at all cost - even if it requires sending an air strike on tens of thousands of civilians or planting the bullet in the head of your ally just because he could possibly spill the information.

Your toolkit consists of stealth, knife, multiple ranged weapons and environmental hazards (incineration, electrocution, explosion).

Being a versatile proffesional you can bypass obstacles in numerous ways - either be it a ghost who goes unnoticed till he reaches his target, gunslinger elliminating enemies with bullets, assassin armed with the knife or a butcher running in berserk and slashing humans like pieces of venison. Game itself is stealth focused so open fight is difficult but possible and fun to master, you can even slash armed enemies to death with your knife if you like so. And the character you play do like it - just look at her facial expression when she slits ones throat - this mocking grim of perversive pleasure of taking ones life gives me the creeps.

Controls could be annoying at the beginning. Player could think that developers were lazy and can't give character simple actions like climbing, jumping, crawling etc. but later in the game you see that our heroine is really mobile and can do everything we need but we are forbidden to do so until special situation occurs. Then we can jump between rooftops, jump over the fances, pull up on the crates, climb ladders, crawl under structures and so on. Just the narration of the story limits our actions. Because this game is about narration, not about open world slaughter-fest.

Combat possibilities are nice and as a mixture of stealth, gunplay and enviro-kill are really enjoyable. You can start encounter by blowing some barrels with silenced pistol thus killing one guard with explosion and when others are alarmed and go to investigate you stab one with the knife and finish the last one with the shot in the head with your gun. And when suddenly another one shows up 'out of nowhere' you activate your adrenaline rush, dash to him and puncture to death. Or simply sneak through. It is up tou your taste or score you want to get at the end of the mission.

Every resource in the game requires you to scavenge the map for its replacement - there is no regeneration of adrenaline, health or armor, no basic gun with infinite ammo and you can't even pick up weapons from fallen enemies. Game gives you strict rules how you should play it and let's you enjoy it in a fair manner.

Stealth is really basic, being in the shadow means you are invisible up to really close range. You can move bodies, wear disguise, peek through keyholes and lure enemies with the whistle. Being spotted doesn't mean restart at the checkpoint, you can still take cover, pull out the gun and fight back or use mentioned adrenaline which enables short bullet-time.

AI is solid and enemies, when alerted, will look behind corners and turn around nervously so you can't just make noise in one place and stab them in the back - they will see you if they pass close by, they can turn around at the moment you don't expect and they will wander around looking for the source of noise. In gunfight expect to be flanked so sitting in one spot and waiting for enemies to walk into your crosshair can end up badly unless you have really good camping site.

I'm 7 hours into the game, counter says it's 8th out of 12 missions and I'm curiously looking forward how will it end, but it is already worth its price [regular 5e] so I can honestly recommend it right now.

reviewText:
Velvet Assassin is a game dating from 2009 that can be found in the bargain bin nowadays. It is presented as a stealth game based on the life of a real English spy although the game itself seems to be mostly made up. The spy in this game is called Violette Summer. You get to steer her through various missions in which you are required to deliver a 'package'. A package could be to kill someone, blow something up or actually deliver something. Usually when the package is delivered the mission ends.

Each mission stands on its own and is unconnected to the others and there isn't something that builds up to a climatic end. While the last mission is highly dramatic, as it refers to a real historic event that involved the deaths of the villagers in a small town in France, it isn't one that follows from those that went before.  There is an overall story told through cut scenes in between the missions.
This story isn't really special, but there is some nice use of lighting in the imagery. One weak point of the story is that you never get a good idea about Violette Summer . There are no sequences in which she interacts with anyone or that give you a feel of what kind of person she is and why she is in the spy business.

A mission usually breaks down in two parts. One part is the sneaking part, the other part, usually the latter, is the fighting part.
The stealth mechanism is something that no stealth veteran would be thrilled about, but if you are impatient and clumsy like me, than it works in a fashion. You can sneak or kill enemies under the noses of others as long as you do it in the dark. When an enemy finds the corpse of one of his fellows he will pursue you quite relentlessly and only sneaking away faster than he walks and keeping hidden al the time makes him give up. When enemies do see you they are pretty deadly and persistent. Otherwise the AI is pretty simple and most enemies will follow predetermined routes.

The combat in the game feels deliberately made awkward as you have to change from sneak mode to combat mode and vice versa because in combat mode you can't pick up items such as bullets or medic kit. Some weapons are pretty powerful, like the Luger, while others, like the Sturmgewehr, feel weak.   Again the ai isn't very smart, and doesn't take cover for instance. So it is numbers, your lack of bullets and your weak weaponry that makes them a danger.

Would I recommend this game?
I finished it in 14 hours of game play. Which means to me that I say yes but only if it is less than 8 dollars/euros and you don't expect too much from it. It isn't worth more.

reviewText:
Velvet Assassin is a game dating from 2009 that can be found in the bargain bin nowadays. It is presented as a stealth game based on the life of a real English spy although the game itself seems to be mostly made up. The spy in this game is called Violette Summer. You get to steer her through various missions in which you are required to deliver a 'package'. A package could be to kill someone, blow something up or actually deliver something. Usually when the package is delivered the mission ends.

Each mission stands on its own and is unconnected to the others and there isn't something that builds up to a climatic end. While the last mission is highly dramatic, as it refers to a real historic event that involved the deaths of the villagers in a small town in France, it isn't one that follows from those that went before.  There is an overall story told through cut scenes in between the missions.
This story isn't really special, but there is some nice use of lighting in the imagery. One weak point of the story is that you never get a good idea about Violette Summer . There are no sequences in which she interacts with anyone or that give you a feel of what kind of person she is and why she is in the spy business.

A mission usually breaks down in two parts. One part is the sneaking part, the other part, usually the latter, is the fighting part.
The stealth mechanism is something that no stealth veteran would be thrilled about, but if you are impatient and clumsy like me, than it works in a fashion. You can sneak or kill enemies under the noses of others as long as you do it in the dark. When an enemy finds the corpse of one of his fellows he will pursue you quite relentlessly and only sneaking away faster than he walks and keeping hidden al the time makes him give up. When enemies do see you they are pretty deadly and persistent. Otherwise the AI is pretty simple and most enemies will follow predetermined routes.

The combat in the game feels deliberately made awkward as you have to change from sneak mode to combat mode and vice versa because in combat mode you can't pick up items such as bullets or medic kit. Some weapons are pretty powerful, like the Luger, while others, like the Sturmgewehr, feel weak.   Again the ai isn't very smart, and doesn't take cover for instance. So it is numbers, your lack of bullets and your weak weaponry that makes them a danger.

Would I recommend this game?
I finished it in 14 hours of game play. Which means to me that I say yes but only if it is less than 8 dollars/euros and you don't expect too much from it. It isn't worth more.
